to easily create workflows that process and publish machine learning\nmodels using Amazon SageMaker and AWS Step Functions. You can create machine learning\nworkflows in Python that orchestrate AWS infrastructure at scale, without having\nto provision and integrate the AWS services separately.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWorkflow - A sequence of steps designed to perform some work\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStep - A unit of work within a workflow\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eML Pipeline - A type of workflow used in data science to create and train machine learning models\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK enables you to do the following.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEasily construct and run machine learning workflows that use AWS\ninfrastructure directly in Python\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInstantiate common training pipelines\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate standard machine learning workflows in a Jupyter notebook that enables you to\ncreate data science and machine learning workflows using AWS Step Functions and\nSageMaker directly in your Python code and Jupyter notebooks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUsing this SDK you can:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate steps that accomplish tasks.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChain those steps together into workflows.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInclude retry, succeed, or fail steps.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReview a graphical representation and definition for your workflow.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate a workflow in AWS Step Functions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStart and review executions in AWS Step Functions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor a detailed API reference of the AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK,\nbe sure to view this documentation on\n\u003ca href=\"https://aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk.readthedocs.io\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eRead the Docs\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-aws-step-functions\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eAWS Step Functions\u003c/h4\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-aws-step-functions\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: AWS Step Functions\" href=\"#aws-step-functions\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAWS Step Functions lets you coordinate multiple AWS services into serverless\nworkflows so you can build and update apps quickly. Using Step Functions, you\ncan design and run workflows that combine services such as Amazon SageMaker, AWS\nLambda, and Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS), into feature-rich\napplications. Workflows are made up of a series of steps, with the output of one\nstep acting as input to the next.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK provides access to AWS Step Functions so that\nyou can easily create and run machine learning and data science workflows\ndirectly in Python, and inside your Jupyter Notebooks. Workflows are created locally\nin Python, but when they are ready for execution, the workflow is first uploaded\nto the AWS Step Functions service for execution in the cloud.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen you use the SDK to create, update, or execute workflows\nyou are talking to the Step Functions service in the cloud. Your workflows\nlive in AWS Step Functions and can be re-used.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can execute a workflow as many times as you want, and you can optionally\nchange the input each time. Each time you execute a workflow, it creates a new\nexecution instance in the cloud. You can inspect these executions with SDK\ncommands, or with the Step Functions management console. You can run more than\none execution at a time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUsing this SDK you can create steps, chain them together to create a workflow,\ncreate that workflow in AWS Step Functions, and execute the workflow in the\nAWS cloud.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/blob/main/doc/images/create.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Create a workflow in AWS Step Functions\" src=\"/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/raw/main/doc/images/create.png\" style=\"width: 600px; max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOnce you have created your workflow in AWS Step Functions, you can execute that\nworkflow in Step Functions, in the AWS cloud.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/blob/main/doc/images/execute.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Start a workflow in AWS Step Functions\" src=\"/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/raw/main/doc/images/execute.png\" style=\"width: 600px; max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eStep Functions creates workflows out of steps called \u003ca href=\"https://docs.aws.amazon.com/step-functions/latest/dg/concepts-states.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eStates\u003c/a\u003e,\nand expresses that workflow in the \u003ca href=\"https://docs.aws.amazon.com/step-functions/latest/dg/concepts-amazon-states-language.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAmazon States Language\u003c/a\u003e.\nWhen you create a workflow in the AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK, it\ncreates a State Machine representing your workflow and steps in AWS Step\nFunctions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor more information about Step Functions concepts and use, see the Step\nFunctions \u003ca href=\"https://docs.aws.amazon.com/step-functions/index.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edocumentation\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-building-a-workflow\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 This protects\nyou from installing a version of the application that contains a virus or other\nmalicious code.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf after running the steps in this topic, you determine that the distribution\nfor the AWS Data Science Workflows Python SDK is altered or corrupted, do NOT\ninstall the package. Instead, contact AWS Support (\u003ca href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/contact-us/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://aws.amazon.com/contact-us/\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAWS Data Science Workflows Python SDK distributions on PyPI are signed using\nGnuPG, an open source implementation of the Pretty Good Privacy (OpenPGP)\nstandard for secure digital signatures. GnuPG (also known as GPG) provides\nauthentication and integrity checking through a digital signature. For more\ninformation about PGP and GnuPG (GPG), see \u003ca href=\"http://www.gnupg.org\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttp://www.gnupg.org\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe first step is to establish trust with the software publisher. Download the\npublic key of the software publisher, check that the owner of the public key is\nwho they claim to be, and then add the public key to your keyring. Your keyring\nis a collection of known public keys. After you establish the authenticity of\nthe public key, you can use it to verify the signature of the application.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-topics\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf your operating system is Linux or Unix, the GPG tools are likely already\ninstalled. To test whether the tools are installed on your system, type\n\u003cstrong\u003egpg\u003c/strong\u003e at a command prompt. If the GPG tools are installed, you see a GPG\ncommand prompt. If the GPG tools are not installed, you see an error stating\nthat the command cannot be found. You can install the GnuPG package from a\nrepository.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo install GPG tools on Debian-based Linux\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFrom a terminal, run the following command: \u003cstrong\u003eapt-get install gnupg\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo install GPG tools on Red Hat–based Linux\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFrom a terminal, run the following command: \u003cstrong\u003eyum install gnupg\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-authenticating-and-importing-the-public-key\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 At a command prompt in the directory where you saved\ndata_science_workflows.key, use the following command to import the AWS Data\nScience Workflows Python SDK public key into your keyring:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre lang=\"text\"\u003egpg --import data_science_workflows.key\n\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe command returns results that are similar to the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre lang=\"text\"\u003egpg: key 60EB103AE314A809: public key \"Stepfunctions-Python-SDK-Signing \u0026lt;stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com\u0026gt;\" imported\ngpg: Total number processed: 1\ngpg:               imported: 1\n\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMake a note of the key value; you need it in the next step. In the preceding\nexample, the key value is 60EB103AE314A809.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e3. Verify the fingerprint by running the following command, replacing key-value\nwith the value from the preceding step:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre lang=\"text\"\u003egpg --fingerprint \u0026lt;key-value\u0026gt;\n\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis command returns results similar to the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre lang=\"text\"\u003epub   rsa4096 2019-10-31 [SC] [expires: 2030-10-31] CC16 0577 B7BF 9D3D 6E5D\n51C5 60EB 103A E314 A809 uid           [ unknown]\nStepfunctions-Python-SDK-Signing\n\u0026lt;stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com\u0026gt; sub   rsa4096 2019-10-31 [E]\n[expires: 2030-10-31]\n\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdditionally, the fingerprint string should be identical to CC16 0577 B7BF\n9D3D 6E5D  51C5 60EB 103A E314 A809, as shown in the preceding example.\nCompare the key fingerprint that is returned to the one published on this\npage. They should match. If they don't match, don't install the AWS Data\nScience Workflows Python SDK package, and contact AWS Support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-verify-the-signature-of-the-package\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAfter you install the GPG tools, authenticate and import the AWS Data Science\nWorkflows Python SDK public key, and verify that the public key is trusted, you\nare ready to verify the signature of the package.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo verify the package signature, do the following.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDownload the detached signature for the package from PyPI\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eGo to the downloads section for the Data Science Workflows Python SDK\n\u003ca href=\"https://pypi.org/project/stepfunctions/#files\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://pypi.org/project/stepfunctions/#files\u003c/a\u003e on PyPI, Right-click on the SDK\ndistribution link, and choose \"Copy Link Location/Address\".\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAppend the string \".asc\" to the end of the link you copied, and paste this\nnew link on your browser.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYour browser will prompt you to download a file, which is the detatched\nsignature associated with the respective distribution. Save the file on your\nlocal machine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e2. Verify the signature by running the following command at a command prompt\nin the directory where you saved signature file and the AWS Data Science\nWorkflows Python SDK installation file. Both files must be present.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre lang=\"text\"\u003egpg --verify \u0026lt;path-to-detached-signature-file\u0026gt;\n\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe output should look something like the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre lang=\"text\"\u003egpg: Signature made Thu 31 Oct 12:14:53 2019 PDT\ngpg:                using RSA key CC160577B7BF9D3D6E5D51C560EB103AE314A809\ngpg: Good signature from \"Stepfunctions-Python-SDK-Signing \u0026lt;stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com\u0026gt;\" [unknown]\ngpg: WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature!\ngpg:          There is no indication that the signature belongs to the owner.\nPrimary key fingerprint: CC16 0577 B7BF 9D3D 6E5D  51C5 60EB 103A E314 A809\n\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf the output contains the phrase Good signature from \"AWS Data Science\nWorkflows Python SDK \u0026lt;stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com\u0026gt;\", it means\nthat the signature has successfully been verified, and you can proceed to run\nthe AWS Data Science Workflows Python SDK package.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf the output includes the phrase BAD signature, check whether you performed the\nprocedure correctly. If you continue to get this response, don't run the\ninstallation file that you downloaded previously, and contact AWS Support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe following are details about the warnings you might see:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre lang=\"text\"\u003eWARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature! There is no\nindication that the signature belongs to the owner. This refers to your\npersonal level of trust in your belief that you possess an authentic public\nkey for AWS Data Science Workflows Python SDK. In an ideal world, you would\nvisit an AWS office and receive the key in person. However, more often you\ndownload it from a website. In this case, the website is an AWS website.\n\ngpg: no ultimately trusted keys found. This means that the specific key is not\n\"ultimately trusted\" by you (or by other people whom you trust).\n\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor more information, see \u003ca href=\"http://www.gnupg.org\" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 Step Functions Data Science SDK is an open-source library that allows datascientists to easily create workflows that process and publish machine learningmodels using Amazon SageMaker and AWS Step Functions. You can create machine learningworkflows in Python that orchestrate AWS infrastructure at scale, without havingto provision and integrate the AWS services separately.</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Workflow - A sequence of steps designed to perform some work</li><li>Step - A unit of work within a workflow</li><li>ML Pipeline - A type of workflow used in data science to create and train machine learning models</li></ul><p dir="auto">The AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK enables you to do the following.</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Easily construct and run machine learning workflows that use AWSinfrastructure directly in Python</li><li>Instantiate common training pipelines</li><li>Create standard machine learning workflows in a Jupyter notebook fromtemplates</li></ul><a Step Functions Data Science SDK provides a Python API that enables you tocreate data science and machine learning workflows using AWS Step Functions andSageMaker directly in your Python code and Jupyter notebooks.</p><p dir="auto">Using this SDK you can:</p><ol dir="auto"><li>Create steps that accomplish tasks.</li><li>Chain those steps together into workflows.</li><li>Include retry, succeed, or fail steps.</li><li>Review a graphical representation and definition for your workflow.</li><li>Create a workflow in AWS Step Functions.</li><li>Start and review executions in AWS Step Functions.</li></ol><p dir="auto">For a detailed API reference of the AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK,be sure to view this documentation on<a href="https://aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk.readthedocs.io" rel="nofollow">Read the Docs</a>.</p><a name="user-content-aws-step-functions"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">AWS Step Functions</h4><a id="user-content-aws-step-functions" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: AWS Step Functions" href="#aws-step-functions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">AWS Step Functions lets you coordinate multiple AWS services into serverlessworkflows so you can build and update apps quickly. Using Step Functions, youcan design and run workflows that combine services such as Amazon SageMaker, AWSLambda, and Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS), into feature-richapplications. Workflows are made up of a series of steps, with the output of onestep acting as input to the next.</p><p dir="auto">The AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK provides access to AWS Step Functions so thatyou can easily create and run machine learning and data science workflowsdirectly in Python, and inside your Jupyter Notebooks. Workflows are created locallyin Python, but when they are ready for execution, the workflow is first uploadedto the AWS Step Functions service for execution in the cloud.</p><p dir="auto">When you use the SDK to create, update, or execute workflowsyou are talking to the Step Functions service in the cloud. Your workflowslive in AWS Step Functions and can be re-used.</p><p dir="auto">You can execute a workflow as many times as you want, and you can optionallychange the input each time. Each time you execute a workflow, it creates a newexecution instance in the cloud. You can inspect these executions with SDKcommands, or with the Step Functions management console. You can run more thanone execution at a time.</p><p dir="auto">Using this SDK you can create steps, chain them together to create a workflow,create that workflow in AWS Step Functions, and execute the workflow in theAWS cloud.</p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/blob/main/doc/images/create.png"><img alt="Create a workflow in AWS Step Functions" src="/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/raw/main/doc/images/create.png" style="width: 600px; max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">Once you have created your workflow in AWS Step Functions, you can execute thatworkflow in Step Functions, in the AWS cloud.</p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/blob/main/doc/images/execute.png"><img alt="Start a workflow in AWS Step Functions" src="/aws/aws-step-functions-data-science-sdk-python/raw/main/doc/images/execute.png" style="width: 600px; max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">Step Functions creates workflows out of steps called <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/step-functions/latest/dg/concepts-states.html" rel="nofollow">States</a>,and expresses that workflow in the <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/step-functions/latest/dg/concepts-amazon-states-language.html" rel="nofollow">Amazon States Language</a>.When you create a workflow in the AWS Step Functions Data Science SDK, itcreates a State Machine representing your workflow and steps in AWS StepFunctions.</p><p dir="auto">For more information about Step Functions concepts and use, see the StepFunctions <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/step-functions/index.html" rel="nofollow">documentation</a>.</p><a name="user-content-building-a-workflow"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Building a Workflow</h3><a id="user-content-building-a-workflow" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Building a Workflow" Then, you can create those workflows in AWS Step Functions andexecute them in Step Functions directly from your Python code. For example,the following is how you define a pass step.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="start_pass_state = Pass(    state_id="MyPassState")"><pre><span class="pl-s1">start_pass_state</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">Pass</span>(    <span class="pl-s1">state_id</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"MyPassState"</span>)</pre></div><p dir="auto">The following is how you define a wait step.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="wait_state = Wait(    state_id="Wait for 3 seconds",    seconds=3)"><pre><span class="pl-s1">wait_state</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">Wait</span>(    <span class="pl-s1">state_id</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Wait for 3 seconds"</span>,    <span class="pl-s1">seconds</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">3</span>)</pre></div><p dir="auto">The following example shows how to define a Lambda step,and then defines a Retry and a Catch.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="lambda_state = LambdaStep(    state_id="Convert HelloWorld to Base64",    parameters={        "FunctionName": "MyLambda", #replace with the name of your function        "Payload": {        "input": "HelloWorld"        }    })lambda_state.add_retry(Retry(    error_equals=["States.TaskFailed"],    interval_seconds=15,    max_attempts=2,    backoff_rate=4.0))lambda_state.add_catch(Catch(    error_equals=["States.TaskFailed"],    next_step=Fail("LambdaTaskFailed")))"><pre><span class="pl-s1">lambda_state</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">LambdaStep</span>(    <span GnuPG (also known as GPG) providesauthentication and integrity checking through a digital signature. For moreinformation about PGP and GnuPG (GPG), see <a href="http://www.gnupg.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.gnupg.org</a>.</p><p dir="auto">The first step is to establish trust with the software publisher. Download thepublic key of the software publisher, check that the owner of the public key iswho they claim to be, and then add the public key to your keyring. Your keyringis a collection of known public keys. class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Installing the GPG Tools</h4><a id="user-content-installing-the-gpg-tools" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Installing the GPG Tools" href="#installing-the-gpg-tools"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">If your operating system is Linux or Unix, the GPG tools are likely alreadyinstalled. To test whether the tools are installed on your system, type<strong>gpg</strong> at a command prompt. If the GPG tools are installed, you see a GPGcommand prompt. If the GPG tools are not installed, you see an error statingthat the command cannot be found. You can install the GnuPG package from arepository.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>To install GPG tools on Debian-based Linux</strong></p><p dir="auto">From a terminal, run the following command: <strong>apt-get install gnupg</strong></p><p dir="auto"><strong>To install GPG tools on Red Hat–based Linux</strong></p><p dir="auto">From a terminal, run the following command: <strong>yum install gnupg</strong></p><a name="user-content-authenticating-and-importing-the-public-key"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Authenticating and Importing the Public Key</h4><a id="user-content-authenticating-and-importing-the-public-key" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Authenticating and Importing the Public Key" href="#authenticating-and-importing-the-public-key"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The next step in the process is to authenticate the AWS Data Science WorkflowsPython SDK public key and add it as a trusted key in your GPG keyring.</p><p dir="auto">To authenticate and import the AWS Data Science Workflows Python SDK public key</p><p dir="auto">1. Copy the key from the following text and paste it into a file calleddata_science_workflows.key. Make sure to include everything that follows:</p><pre lang="text">-----BEGIN PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK----------END PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----</pre><p dir="auto">2. At a command prompt in the directory where you saveddata_science_workflows.key, use the following command to import the AWS DataScience Workflows Python SDK public key into your keyring:</p><pre lang="text">gpg --import data_science_workflows.key</pre><p dir="auto">The command returns results that are similar to the following:</p><pre lang="text">gpg: key 60EB103AE314A809: public key "Stepfunctions-Python-SDK-Signing <stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com>" importedgpg: Total number processed: 1gpg:               imported: 1</pre><p dir="auto">Make a note of the key value; you need it in the next step. In the precedingexample, the key value is 60EB103AE314A809.</p><p dir="auto">3. Verify the fingerprint by running the following command, replacing key-valuewith the value from the preceding step:</p><pre lang="text">gpg --fingerprint <key-value></pre><p dir="auto">This command returns results similar to the following:</p><pre lang="text">pub   rsa4096 2019-10-31 [SC] [expires: 2030-10-31] CC16 0577 B7BF 9D3D 6E5D51C5 60EB 103A E314 A809 uid           [ unknown]Stepfunctions-Python-SDK-Signing<stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com> sub   rsa4096 2019-10-31 [E][expires: 2030-10-31]</pre><p dir="auto">Additionally, the fingerprint string should be identical to CC16 0577 B7BF9D3D 6E5D  51C5 60EB 103A E314 A809, as shown in the preceding example.Compare the key fingerprint that is returned to the one published on thispage. They should match. If they don't match, don't install the AWS DataScience Workflows Python SDK package, and contact AWS Support.</p><a name="user-content-verify-the-signature-of-the-package"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Verify the Signature of the Package</h4><a id="user-content-verify-the-signature-of-the-package" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Verify the Signature of the Package" href="#verify-the-signature-of-the-package"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">After you install the GPG tools, authenticate and import the AWS Data ScienceWorkflows Python SDK public key, and verify that the public key is trusted, youare ready to verify the signature of the package.</p><p dir="auto">To verify the package signature, do the following.</p><ol dir="auto"><li>Download the detached signature for the package from PyPI</li></ol><blockquote><p dir="auto">Go to the downloads section for the Data Science Workflows Python SDK<a href="https://pypi.org/project/stepfunctions/#files" rel="nofollow">https://pypi.org/project/stepfunctions/#files</a> on PyPI, Right-click on the SDKdistribution link, and choose "Copy Link Location/Address".</p><p dir="auto">Append the string ".asc" to the end of the link you copied, and paste thisnew link on your browser.</p><p dir="auto">Your browser will prompt you to download a file, which is the detatchedsignature associated with the respective distribution. Save the file on yourlocal machine.</p></blockquote><p dir="auto">2. Verify the signature by running the following command at a command promptin the directory where you saved signature file and the AWS Data ScienceWorkflows Python SDK installation file. Both files must be present.</p><pre lang="text">gpg --verify <path-to-detached-signature-file></pre><p dir="auto">The output should look something like the following:</p><pre lang="text">gpg: Signature made Thu 31 Oct 12:14:53 2019 PDTgpg:                using RSA key CC160577B7BF9D3D6E5D51C560EB103AE314A809gpg: Good signature from "Stepfunctions-Python-SDK-Signing <stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com>" [unknown]gpg: WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature!gpg:          There is no indication that the signature belongs to the owner.Primary key fingerprint: CC16 0577 B7BF 9D3D 6E5D  51C5 60EB 103A E314 A809</pre><p dir="auto">If the output contains the phrase Good signature from "AWS Data ScienceWorkflows Python SDK <stepfunctions-developer-experience [at] amazon.com>", it meansthat the signature has successfully been verified, and you can proceed to runthe AWS Data Science Workflows Python SDK package.</p><p dir="auto">If the output includes the phrase BAD signature, check whether you performed theprocedure correctly. If you continue to get this response, don't run theinstallation file that you downloaded previously, and contact AWS Support.</p><p dir="auto">The following are details about the warnings you might see:</p><pre lang="text">WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature! There is noindication that the signature belongs to the owner. This refers to yourpersonal level of trust in your belief that you possess an authentic publickey for AWS Data Science Workflows Python SDK. In an ideal world, you wouldvisit an AWS office and receive the key in person. However, more often youdownload it from a website. In this case, the website is an AWS website.gpg: no ultimately trusted keys found. This means that the specific key is not"ultimately trusted" by you (or by other people whom you trust).</pre><p dir="auto">For more information, see <a href="http://www.gnupg.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.gnupg.org</a>.</p></article></div></div></div></div></div> <!-- --> <!-- --> <script type="application/json"
